Common Issues

Why People Leave Metro by T-Mobile

Expensive Unlimited Plans

Metro's unlimited plans cost $50-$60/month, significantly more than competitors offering similar features on comparable or better networks.

Constant Data Deprioritization

Metro customers are always deprioritized behind T-Mobile postpaid users, meaning slower speeds during busy times in congested areas.

Rural Coverage Gaps

Despite T-Mobile improvements, Metro still has weaker coverage in rural areas and some suburbs compared to AT&T-based carriers.

In-Store Experience Required

Many Metro transactions require visiting a physical store, adding inconvenience compared to fully online carriers with easy self-service.

FAQ

Switching from Metro by T-Mobile

Common questions about making the switch

Absolutely! Your phone number belongs to you, not Metro. When switching, provide your new carrier with your Metro account number and PIN. The port usually completes in minutes to a few hours. Don't cancel Metro before the port completes.

Most Metro phones from 2019 onwards support multiple networks and will work on AT&T. Your phone needs to be unlocked (Metro unlocks phones after 180 days of active service) and support AT&T's LTE bands. iPhones and most Samsung Galaxy phones work seamlessly.

Metro charges a premium for their retail store presence and brand recognition. You're paying for the convenience of in-store support and phone deals. Online-first carriers like Vouch Mobile pass those savings to customers, offering similar or better service for less.

In rural areas and many suburbs, yes. AT&T has traditionally stronger coverage outside major cities. In urban areas, both networks perform similarly. If you've experienced dead zones or weak signal with Metro, Vouch Mobile on AT&T may provide better coverage.

Metro's unlimited plan costs $60/month while Vouch Mobile's unlimited is $30/month - a savings of $30/month or $360/year. You get better AT&T coverage and convenient online service, making the switch both cheaper and more convenient.
